questions.question: What is the normal artery-to-vein ratio at the optic disc margin?
questions.explanation: This ratio is clinically important in assessing retinal vascular changes. A significantly reduced A:V ratio suggests worsening microvascular disease and increased risk of retinal complications. Hypertension can reduce the A:V ratio (e.g., 1:3 or 1:4) due to arteriolar narrowing. Diabetes mellitus may also cause changes, but typically with venous dilatation and beading. Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC9333006/ https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5437764/

questions.question: Which of the following conditions is not managed using the spectacles depicted in the image?
questions.explanation: intraocular lens (IOL) in the eye of a child who has had their natural lens removed, usually due to a cataract or other congenital eye conditions. In this case, spectacles are not used for vision correction because an IOL is implanted to replace the natural lens. Spectacles may be used for certain specific purposes like near vision, but the primary correction for vision comes from the intraocular lens. Incorrect Options: The spectacles shown in the image are bifocal spectacles, which contain two different types of optical power. Bifocal spectacles are commonly used for the management of : Option A. Presbyopia: Presbyopia is an age-related condition where the natural lens of the eye loses its ability to focus on near objects due to a gradual loss of elasticity. Bifocal spectacles are often prescribed for individuals with presbyopia to correct both their distance vision and near vision. The upper part of the lens is for distance vision, while the lower part contains an additional segment called a "reading segment" for near vision. Option B. Aphakia: Aphakia refers to the absence of the natural lens of the eye, which may occur due to surgical removal or congenital absence. In aphakic individuals, bifocal spectacles can be prescribed to address both their distance vision and near vision needs, similar to the management of presbyopia. Option D. Hypermetropia: Hypermetropia, or farsightedness, is a refractive error that can be corrected with prescription eyeglasses to help focus light properly on the retina. Reference: .

questions.question: What would be the recommended treatment for simple myopic astigmatism among the following options?
questions.explanation: where there is nearsightedness (myopia) combined with astigmatism. The prescription format for astigmatism includes a spherical component (DS) and a cylindrical component (DC) with a specific axis (in degrees). In this case, -1.00 DC × 180 degrees indicates that there is 1.00 diopter of astigmatism in the minus cylinder form along the 180-degree axis. Incorrect Options: Option A: +1.00 DS- A positive value in the spherical component (+DS) indicates hyperopia (farsightedness), which is not suitable for simple myopic astigmatism. Option C: -1.00 DS- While it addresses myopia (nearsightedness), it does not account for the presence of astigmatism. Simple myopic astigmatism requires correction for both nearsightedness and astigmatism. Option D: -1.00 DS - 1.00 × 180 degrees- The addition of "-1.00" in front of the cylinder component suggests a double correction, which is unnecessary in simple myopic astigmatism. The correct format should include a single cylindrical component.

questions.question: What would be the suitable course of action for managing a 15-year-old girl who is non-adherent to wearing spectacles for her myopic astigmatism?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B - Spherical equivalent spectacles The most appropriate management for a 15-year-old girl who is not compliant with spectacles for her myopic astigmatism would be spherical equivalent spectacles. Spherical equivalent spectacles provide correction for both myopia (nearsightedness) and astigmatism. They are a non-invasive and reversible option that can effectively improve visual acuity and provide clear vision when worn. Management options for Astigmatism: Optical Spectacles: with cylindrical power correction/ spherical equivalent spectacles is the initial treatment option especially for paediatric age group (Option B) Rigid contact lenses: for up to 3D Toric contact lenses: for > 3D astigmatism cases Refractive Procedures Phototherapeutic keratectomy: Using excimer lens, for irregular astigmatism, can correct up to 3D LASIK (Laser-Assisted In Situ Keratomileusis): can correct up to 5D IOL implantation: Toric IOLs are preferred using Collamer lenses Surgical Penetrating or Deep Lamellar Anterior Keratoplasty (DLAK): in cases of corneal scarring/ no improvement with other treatment modalities Incorrect Options: LASIK (Option A) (Laser-Assisted In Situ Keratomileusis): is a surgical procedure that reshapes the cornea to correct refractive errors. It involves creating a corneal flap and using a laser to remove tissue. LASIK is generally not recommended for individuals under the age of 18 as their eyes are still developing. It is also important to consider the patient's non-compliance with spectacles, which raises concerns about their readiness for a surgical procedure. Femto LASIK (Option C): is a variation of LASIK that uses a femtosecond laser to create the corneal flap. Similar to LASIK, it is a surgical procedure and carries the same considerations and limitations mentioned above. Implantable collamer lens (Option D): is a type of intraocular lens that is surgically implanted in the eye to correct refractive errors. It involves placing a lens inside the eye, typically in front of the natural lens. Like LASIK, this is a surgical option that may not be suitable for a non-compliant patient, especially considering the patient's age. Reference: AK Khurana Textbook of Ophthalmology 7th Edition, Page 44,216. Kanski Clinical Ophthalmology, 10th edition, Pages 284,285.

questions.question: In the image provided, which refractive error is observed in the depicted condition? about 15 times

options.A: A condensing lens is not required
options.B: B) It is used as close to the patient’s eye as possible. A real, inverted image is seen, Magnification is
options.C: A real, inverted image is seen

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Magnification is about 15 times Explanation: Instrument shown in the image is that of a Direct ophthalmoscope , where a virtual, erect image is produced with magnification of about 15 times . Direct and Indirect Ophthalmoscope: Direct Ophthalmoscope Indirect Ophthalmoscope Image Virtual image, erect (Option B & C) Real image, inverted Magnification 15x magnification (Option D) 2-3x magnification Condensing lens Used (Option A) Not required Visualization Uniocular Binocular Field of view 2 DD 8 DD Advantages Undilated pupil Stereopsis present Entire retina can be seen Visualization through hazy media is possible

questions.question: Which of the following lenses would be recommended to correct myopia?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Concave Explanation: Concave lenses (diverging lenses) are used to correct Myopia. Myopia - management: General measures Balanced diet Visual hygiene: Posture correction, adequate illumination, reducing usage of video display units (VDUs) Optical Concave lenses are prescribed: Spectacles/ contact lenses (Option B) Surgical Radial Keratotomy (RK): Used for low to moderate myopia (2-6 D). No longer recommended due to the advent of safer procedures like LASIK. Photorefractive Keratectomy (PRK): It uses an excimer laser to reshape the cornea by removing a thin corneal layer. Suitable for correcting myopia up to -6 D. Refractive Lenticule Extraction (SMILE): A minimally invasive laser procedure where a small lenticule is removed to reshape the cornea. Effective for myopia up to -10 D, with or without astigmatism. Phakic Intraocular Lens (IOL) Implantation: Implantable lens placed without removing the natural lens. Best for myopia exceeding -8 D, especially in patients unsuitable for laser surgery. Convex lens (Option A): Used in the case of presbyopia and in the case of hypermetropia . Cylindrical lens (Option C): Used for correction of astigmatism . Abraham lens (Option D): A 66 D lens used for peripheral iridotomy with Nd:Yag laser .

questions.question: In a 3-year-old child who has recently developed 15-degree accommodative esotropia, what is the most effective treatment approach?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Refractive correction Explanation: Refraction correction would be the most effective treatment approach in a child with Accommodative esotropia . Accommodative esotropia: Accommodative Refractive Esotropia Accommodative Non-refractive Esotropia Accommodative Mixed Esotropia Cause High hypermetropia (+4 to +7 D) Abnormal large AC/A (accommodative convergence/accommodation) ratio Combination of hypermetropia and high AC/ A ratio Treatment Correction of hypermetropia (spectacles) Corrected by bifocal glasses with +3 DS added for near vision Miotics (Echothiophate) Surgery: Bilateral medial rectus recession Surgery: Bilateral medial rectus recession Orthoptic exercise (Option A): Orthoptic exercises are used for the improvement in the binocular vision to treat paralytic squint . Surgery (Option B): Surgeries are generally performed to treat non-refractive/ non-accommodative esotropia . INTACS (Option D): INTACS (intracorneal ring segments) are used for the management of keratoconus. Reference: Parsons Diseases of the eye 23rd Edition, pages 979- 982. Yanoff & Duker Ophthalmology 5th edition, pages 1212,1213. A K KhuranaComprehensive Ophthalmology 7th edition, page 363.

questions.question: The probable cause for a patient with a corneal scar having a visual acuity of 6/36, which improves to 6/18 with a pinhole, is most likely due to...
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Irregular astigmatism Explanation: Improvement in visual acuity with a pinhole is suggestive of a refractive error . Among the given options, Irregular astigmatism is the only refractive error. The pinhole test reduces the amount of light scattering in the eye and sharpens vision by narrowing the beam of light entering the pupil. Pinhole and Stenopeic slit tests: Pinhole Test Stenopeic Slit Test Mechanism Uses a small opaque disc with holes to reduce retinal blur and improve visual acuity in refractive errors up to 4D. Uses a narrow slit to reduce peripheral aberrations and enhance depth of focus. Clinical Applications Determines if reduced vision is due to refractive errors; vision improvement suggests a refractive issue. (Option C) Quick assessment of visual acuity, often in under-resourced settings. WHO recommended blindness surveys. To assess astigmatism, especially irregular astigmatism (as it allows for a more detailed analysis of the patient's visual field by focusing light along a single axis) or complex visual issues. A stenopeic slit is used in cases of corneal opacities to help identify the best location for an optical iridectomy. Limitations Can underestimate post-refractive visual acuity. Reduces light reaching the retina, potentially causing diffraction blur. Limited mainly to complex refractive issues.

questions.question: During a routine eye examination, a patient's visual acuity was evaluated using Snellen's chart, and it was determined to be 6/6. What is the smallest angle at which this patient can differentiate two separate points or objects?
questions.explanation: acuity , which is the ability to see clearly at a distance of 6 meters what should normally be seen at that distance. The smallest angle at which the eye can differentiate two points is referred to as the angular resolution of the eye. For a person with normal vision (6/6), this is approximately 1 minute of arc per line on the Snellen chart. However, the smallest angular separation that the human eye can typically distinguish under optimal conditions is 5 minutes of arc . This corresponds to the smallest angle at which a person with normal vision can resolve two separate points as distinct. Normal visual acuity (6/6) corresponds to a subtended angle of 5 minutes of arc. Snellen’s chart Measures visual acuity by assessing the eye's ability to distinguish details or separate points. Rows of decreasing-sized letters fit within squares. Each letter subtends an angle of 5 minutes, and the lines forming letters subtend 1 minute of arc. Visual Acuity Notation Snellen Fraction: Denoted as a fraction, with the numerator being 6 meters and the denominator indicating the distance at which normal vision reads the same letter (e.g., 6/18 means the patient reads at 6 meters what normal vision reads at 18 meters). Metric/Imperial: 6/6 = 20/20 vision. Decimal Acuity: 6/6 equals 1.0 decimal acuity. Testing Procedure The patient is positioned 6 meters from the chart, and each eye is tested individually, starting with the right eye. The patient reads the smallest visible letter. Limitations Refractive Errors: Primarily measures uncorrected vision. Pinhole tests help detect refractive errors that can be corrected with lenses. Subjectivity: Dependent on patient literacy, language, and cognitive ability. Scope: Assesses only visual acuity, not contrast sensitivity, color vision, or peripheral vision. 15 minutes of arc (Option A) : This is too large an angle for normal visual acuity. It corresponds to a less sharp visual resolution. 10 minutes of arc (Option C) : This is also larger than the typical 5 minutes of arc resolution of normal vision. 20 minutes of arc (Option D) : This is even larger and would correspond to a more impaired level of visual acuity.

questions.question: When selecting the strength of an intraocular lens (IOL) for a child under 1 year old, what factors should be considered?
questions.explanation: age, the myopic shift should be taken into account. A myopic shift is a phenomenon where the eye becomes more myopic as it grows, and this can lead to a child becoming increasingly nearsighted over time. To compensate for this, a lower power IOL should be chosen to allow for the myopic shift that will occur as the child's eye grows. The length of the lens capsule and growth of the lens capsule are important factors to consider when selecting an IOL, but they are not the primary factors in choosing the power of the IOL in a young child. Incorrect Options: Option B - Hypermetropic shift: Hypermetropic shift is not a relevant factor in choosing the power of an IOL in a child under 1 year of age. The hypermetropic shift is the phenomenon where the eye becomes more hyperopic as it grows, and this is not typically observed in young children. Option C - Length of the lens capsule: The length of the lens capsule is an important factor to consider when selecting an IOL, but it is not the primary factor in choosing the power of the IOL in a young child. Option D - Growth of the lens capsule: The growth of the lens capsule is an important factor to consider when selecting an IOL, but it is not the primary factor in choosing the power of the IOL in a young child.

questions.question: What is the probable medical condition for a 70-year-old individual who has relied on presbyopia glasses but can now comfortably read the newspaper without them?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - Index myopia: Myopia=shortsightedness- refractive error where parallel rays of light from distant objects focus in front of the retina when the eye's accommodation is relaxed. Index myopia is a condition that often occurs in older individuals, typically associated with age-related changes in the lens . As we age, the lens of the eye becomes denser and less flexible, which can lead to myopia (nearsightedness) in some cases. In index myopia , the refractive index of the lens increases, causing a shift in the focal point of the eye, making it easier for a person to focus on nearby objects, like reading a newspaper, without the aid of reading glasses. This would explain why the 70-year-old patient, who had been using presbyopia glasses (for near vision), is now able to read comfortably without them. Type of Myopia Cause Axial Myopia Increase in the anteroposterior length of the eyeball (most common form). Curvatural Myopia Increased curvature of the cornea, lens, or both. Positional Myopia Anterior placement of the crystalline lens in the eye. Index Myopia Increase in the refractive index of the crystalline lens, often due to nuclear sclerosis. Myopia due to Excessive Accommodation Caused by spasm of accommodation, leading to excessive focusing power. Clinical features Asthenopic symptoms Half-shutting of eyes for better clarity Prominent eyeball. Prominent, large, and somewhat sluggishly reacting pupils. Slightly deeper anterior chamber. Normal fundus; rarely a temporal myopic crescent may be seen. Treatment Prescription of appropriate concave lenses Surgical Treatment Index hypermetropia (Option B) : This would cause the opposite effect of index myopia . In this condition, the lens of the eye becomes more hypermetropic (farsighted), making near objects harder to focus on, which would make reading more difficult, not easier. Therefore, this is not consistent with the patient's improvement in near vision. Presbyopia (Option C) : This condition is a normal aging process that causes the loss of accommodation (the ability to focus on near objects). Presbyopia usually results in difficulty reading without corrective lenses (reading glasses). If the patient no longer needs glasses for reading, it is unlikely that they simply have presbyopia. The improvement in near vision suggests a different mechanism, such as index myopia . None of the above (Option D) : This option is incorrect because index myopia is a plausible explanation for the patient's improvement in near vision. Reference: Myron Yanoff and Duker’s textbook of ophthalmology, 6th edition, Page no: 28-30 Defining and Classifying Myopia

questions.question: Which of the following refractive errors is associated with the image given below?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Astigmatism Explanation: Astigmatism is a refractive error caused by an irregular shape of the cornea or lens, leading to blurred or distorted vision . This results in multiple focal points instead of a single point of focus on the retina. The image shows irregular, blurry distorted vision or varying focal points and is typically associated with astigmatism , where light entering the eye is refracted unevenly. Astigmatism A refractive error where the eye's refraction varies across different meridians. As a result, light rays entering the eye do not converge to a single point, instead form focal lines. Regular Astigmatism Refractive power changes uniformly from one meridian to another. There are 2 principal meridians. Oblique Astigmatism- two principal meridians are not horizontal and vertical but are at right angles to each other (e.g., 45° and 135°). Bioblique Astigmatism- two principal meridians are not at right angles to each other (e.g., one at 30° and the other at 100°). Irregular Astigmatism Irregular change in refractive power in different meridians, with multiple meridians that do not admit geometrical analysis Incorrect Options: Presbyopia (Option A) : This is an age-related condition where the eye's ability to focus on near objects decreases, typically around age 40. It causes difficulty in reading or seeing close objects, but it's not associated with distorted vision like astigmatism. Hypermetropia (Option C) (Farsightedness) : In hypermetropia, distant objects are seen clearly, but near objects appear blurry. This is due to a shorter eyeball or less curved cornea , not irregular refraction. Myopia (Option D) (Nearsightedness) : In myopia, nearby objects are seen clearly, but distant objects appear blurry, typically due to a longer eyeball or steeper cornea . It does not cause distorted vision as seen in astigmatism.

questions.question: A 21 year old boxer wanted to improve the vision . Which of the following surgery is contraindicated?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) RK Explanation: Radial Keratotomy (RK) involves making radial incisions in the cornea to flatten it and correct myopia. It is no longer recommended due to its unstable results and the risk of complications , especially in young, active individuals. For a 21-year-old boxer , RK is contraindicated because it compromises the structural integrity of the cornea, increasing the risk of corneal weakening and potential rupture due to trauma, which is a significant concern in contact sports. Refractive surgeries for myopia Incisional Method Radial Keratotomy (RK) Involves radial cuts in the cornea to flatten it, correcting myopia. Used for low to moderate myopia (2-6 D). No longer recommended due to the advent of safer procedures like LASIK. Newer Methods Photorefractive Keratectomy (PRK) (Option B ruled out) It uses an excimer laser to reshape the cornea by removing a thin corneal layer. Suitable for correcting myopia up to -6 D. Refractive Lenticule Extraction (SMILE) : (Option D ruled out) A minimally invasive laser procedure where a small lenticule is removed to reshape the cornea. Effective for myopia up to -10 D, with or without astigmatism. Intercorneal Rings (ICR) : Rings are inserted into the cornea to flatten it and reduce refractive power. Results can be unpredictable, with risks such as corneal inflammation, so is not recommended Orthokeratology A non-surgical and reversible method involving rigid contact lenses worn overnight to reshape the cornea. Corrects myopia up to -5 D temporarily. High Myopia Solutions Clear Lens Extraction Removal of the natural lens (without cloudiness) to correct very high myopia (-16 D to -18 D). Less common now due to risks like retinal detachment. Phakic Intraocular Lens (IOL) Implantation Implantable lens placed without removing the natural lens. Best for myopia exceeding -8 D, especially in patients unsuitable for laser surgery. PRK , LASIK , and SMILE are safer alternatives for myopia correction and are well-suited for active individuals like athletes. These methods involve laser reshaping of the cornea with less risk of trauma-related complications than RK. Reference: Myron Yanoff and Duker’s textbook of ophthalmology, 6th edition, Page no: 284-286

questions.question: A patient was prescribed with -1D spherical and -2D cylindrical at 180 degrees. What type of refractive error does this patient have?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) With the rule astigmatism Explanation: The prescription given is -1D spherical and -2D cylindrical at 180 degrees . The spherical component (-1D) indicates a myopic refractive error. The cylindrical component (-2D) at 180 degrees indicates astigmatism with the steepest curvature along the 180-degree axis. In with-the-rule astigmatism , the steepest curvature (and therefore the highest cylinder value) is along the vertical axis (90 degrees), and the flatter axis is horizontal (0 or 180 degrees). Since the cylinder is placed at 180 degrees and the patient has a more negative cylindrical value at this axis, it indicates with-the-rule astigmatism . With-the-Rule Astigmatism (WTR) Against-the-Rule Astigmatism (ATR) The vertical meridian is more curved than the horizontal. Correction requires a concave cylindrical lens at 180° ± 20° or a convex cylindrical lens at 90° ± 20°. It is called "with-the-rule" because the vertical meridian is normally more convex than the horizontal due to eyelid pressure. The horizontal meridian is more curved than the vertical meridian. Correction requires a convex cylindrical lens at 180° ± 20° or a concave cylindrical lens at 90° ± 20°. 180 degrees 90 Degrees With the rule [-] [+] Against the rule [+] [-] Against the rule astigmatism (Option B) : This occurs when the steepest curvature is along the horizontal axis (0 or 180 degrees) and the flatter axis is vertical (90 degrees), which is not the case here. Simple astigmatism (Option C) : This refers to astigmatism where one of the meridians has no refractive error (i.e., it's either emmetropic or has no cylinder correction), but this patient has both spherical and cylindrical components. Mixed astigmatism (Option D) : This occurs when one axis has a myopic refractive error and the other has a hypermetropic refractive error. In this case, the prescription is purely myopic in both axes. Reference: Myron Yanoff and Duker’s textbook of ophthalmology, 6th edition, Page no: 39 Astigmatism

questions.question: Which of the following do not represent the corrected refractive error?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Presbyopia Explanation: Presbyopia does not represent in the above given image Presbyopia happens around the age of 40 years for an emmetropic person, less than 40 years in hypermetropic patients, and more than 40 years for myopic patients. At 40 years, around +1 D spherical lens is used to correct it. With every year that passes, around 0.5 D increases happen. The first image is of Myopia correction -It is done by concave lens Second image is of Hyperopia correction -It is done by convex lens Third image is of Astigmatism correction -It is done by cylindrical lens Definition Physiological insufficiency of accommodation is typically associated with aging. Etio - Pathogenesis Age-related factors: Decreased elasticity of the lens capsule. Sclerosis of the lens. Possible decline in ciliary muscle power. Premature causes: Uncorrected hypermetropia Chronic glaucoma Symptoms Difficulty in near vision Asthenopic symptoms (eye fatigue) Intermittent diplopia Treatment Options Optical Treatment: Convex glasses based on age Correct refractive error for distance first Types of Glasses: Unifocal, bifocal, or progressive (varifocal). Pharmacological therapy:1.25% Pilocarpine (FDA-approved) Surgical options: Conductive keratoplasty LASIK (Monovision/presbyopic multifocal-LASIK) Corneal inlays Multifocal IOL placement following lens extraction

questions.question: What diagnosis is suggested by having different refractive powers (+5D in one eye and +1D in the other eye)?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Anisometropic amblyopia Explanation: In this scenario, the child has two different refractive powers in both eyes; +5D in one eye and +1D in the other eye. Anisometropia is the difference between the refractive power of both eyes when > 2.5 D. Anisometropia can lead to Amblyopia Amblyopia: Definition, Types, and Clinical Characteristics Definition: Partial, reversible vision loss in one or both eyes. Absence of organic diseases of ocular media, retina, visual pathway The eye appears normal, but vision is impaired. Types of Amblyopia: Type Cause Key Features Strabismic Amblyopia The brain suppresses input from one eye due to constant squint (strabismus). Common cause; underdevelopment of vision in the deviated eye. Stimulus Deprivation Amblyopia Hindered vision due to obstruction from early life (e.g., congenital cataracts, ptosis, dense central corneal opacity) . Lack of visual stimulation affects normal development. Anisometropic Amblyopia (Option C ruled out) A significant difference in refractive error between eyes. The brain favours the clearer eye, leading to amblyopia in the other. Ametropic Amblyopia High uncorrected refractive errors in both eyes. Bilateral; is less severe compared to other types. Meridional Amblyopia Uncorrected astigmatism affecting specific visual meridians. Affects one or both eyes depending on the astigmatism degree. Refractive errors (Option A) While the condition involves refractive errors, the key point is the significant difference in refractive powers between the two eyes. This disparity leads to anisometropia, which can cause amblyopia. General refractive errors alone do not necessarily lead to amblyopia. Malingering (Option D) refers to the deliberate faking of symptoms. Reference: Kanski’s clinical ophthalmology, John F. Salmon, 10th edition, Page no: 718-719 Amblyopia - PMC

questions.question: What is Anisometropia ?

options.B: Difference in refractive error between 2 eyes
options.C: Difference in the axial length of the eyeball

questions.explanation: refraction of the two eyes is unequal. The difference in power of two eyes is more than 2.5 diopters. Anisometropia up to 2.5D is well tolerated and that between 2.5 and 4D can be tolerated depending upon the individual sensitivity. However, if it is more than 4D, it is not tolerated and is a matter of concern. Incorrect Options: Option A - Difference in visual acuity: Differences in visual acuity could be caused by conditions like myopia, hypermetropia, astigmatism, and presbyopia. Option C - Difference in axial length: The difference in the axial length of the eyeball is seen in axial myopia. Option D - Difference in size of eyeball: The difference in the size of the eyeball is seen in conditions like Microphthalmia and Buphthalmos. Reference: .

questions.question: During the Worth 4 Dot Test, a patient sees only three green dots. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Right eye suppression is diagnosed when the patient reports seeing only three green dots. Incorrect Options: Option B: A patient with left eye suppression will only see two red dots. Option C and D: A patient with diplopia will see five dots- two red and three green dots. Reference: .

questions.question: What is the term used to describe the refractive error seen in the ocular examination image of a 60-year-old patient who has complained of reduced distant vision, but no longer requires spectacles for near vision?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Index myopia Explanation: Myopia = shortsightedness- refractive error where parallel rays of light from distant objects focus in front of the retina when the eye's accommodation is relaxed. Index myopia is a condition that often occurs in older individuals, typically associated with age-related changes in the lens . As we age, the lens of the eye becomes denser and less flexible, which can lead to myopia (nearsightedness) in some cases. The patient has reduced distant vision (a hallmark of myopia) but no longer needs glasses for near vision , which suggests that the lens has become more myopic (thicker or more curved) and is compensating for the near vision loss that typically occurs with presbyopia. Index myopia is usually caused by the increase in refractive index of the lens with age, making it more myopic, particularly for distance vision. Type of Myopia Cause Axial Myopia Increase in the anteroposterior length of the eyeball (most common form). Curvatural Myopia Increased curvature of the cornea, lens, or both. Positional Myopia Anterior placement of the crystalline lens in the eye. Index Myopia Increase in the refractive index of the crystalline lens, often due to nuclear sclerosis. Myopia due to Excessive Accommodation Caused by spasm of accommodation, leading to excessive focusing power. Clinical features Asthenopic symptoms Half-shutting of eyes for better clarity Prominent eyeball. Prominent, large, and somewhat sluggishly reacting pupils. Slightly deeper anterior chamber. Normal fundus; rarely a temporal myopic crescent may be seen. Treatment Prescription of appropriate concave lenses Surgical Treatment Incorrect Options: Axial myopia (Option B) : Caused by an elongated eyeball . This typically leads to myopia from birth or early in life and doesn’t relate to the lens changes seen with aging. Curvatural myopia (Option C) : Caused by a change in the curvature of the cornea , which affects the focusing power of the eye. It’s

questions.question: A 22-year-old patient with high myopia and thick glasses presents with floaters in his eyes. What is the likely cause of this condition? occlusion

options.A: Subarachnoid hemorrhage B) Retinal detachment C) Vitreous hemorrhage D) Branched retinal artery

questions.explanation: progressive error that starts in childhood at 5-10 years of age and results in high myopia (>-6D) during early adult life. Etiology Rapid axial growth of the eyeball outside normal biological variations Genetic factors (major role) More common in women than men Autosomal dominant pathological myopia Heredity- Familial, more common in women and in certain races Autosomal Dominant - linked to genes 18p11.31 and 12q21-23 Sex-linked recessive - high myopia (>6D) General growth process (minor role) nutritional deficiency endocrine disturbances Symptoms Defective vision with considerable failure in visual function Muscae volitantes (floaters) Difficulty in night vision in very high myopes with degenerative changes Signs Prominent eyeballs, often appear elongated Exophthalmos, especially in unilateral cases Cornea is large The anterior chamber is deep Pupils are slightly large and react sluggishly to light Fundus examination reveals: The optic disc appears large and pale Characteristic myopic crescent Tigroid fundus Myopic crescent (temporal to disc margin) Complications Retinal detachment (Option B) Complicated cataract Choroidal hemorrhage and neovascularization Vitreous hemorrhage Primary open-angle glaucoma (associated condition) Degenerative changes in the retina and choroid: Chorioretinal atrophy at the macula Foster-Fuchs spots Lattice degeneration Total retinal atrophy Posterior staphyloma Degenerative changes in vitreous: Liquefaction Vitreous opacities Posterior vitreous detachment Subarachnoid hemorrhage (Option A) causes subhyaloid hemorrhage. Vitreous hemorrhage (Option C) is caused by blunt force trauma and is not commonly associated with high myopia Branched retinal artery occlusion (Option D) presents with a cherry red spot in the retina.

questions.question: Which of the following is a cause of bilateral sudden painless loss of vision?
questions.explanation: sudden vision loss due to complications. Bilateral sudden painless loss of vision can be caused by diabetic retinopathy, particularly in its proliferative form, where there is a sudden onset of vision loss due macular edema, or retinal detachment. Diabetic retinopathy affects both eyes and can lead to significant vision impairment if left untreated. Clinical Features of Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (PDR): Includes all features of preproliferative diabetic retinopathy or severe NPDR: Multiple retinal hemorrhages, cotton-wool spots, venous beading, vascular loops, intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMAs), and large areas of capillary nonperfusion along with neovascularization. Neovascularization (2 types): Neovascularization of the Disc (NVD): Arises within 1 disc diameter of the optic nerve from the optic nerve head. Neovascularization Elsewhere (NVE): Arises more than 1 disc diameter from the optic nerve, along the large vessels. Appears adjacent to areas of capillary closure and the accompanying fibrous tissue varies in extent. Fluorescein angiography (FA): Irregular expanding hyperfluorescence. Severe Vision Loss: Result in vision as poor as hand movements or worse due to severe vitreous hemorrhage or retinal detachment. Fibrovascular Tissue Formation: Formed due to condensation of connective tissue around the new vessels. Lie flat on the retina or attach to the posterior vitreous face. Can lead to vitreous traction, retinal separation, and blood vessel tearing. The most common cause of vitreous hemorrhage in adults. Rubeosis Iridis: Neovascularization of iris. Neovascular glaucoma: Occurs due neovascularization of anterior segment angle. Acute congestive glaucoma (Option A): Acute congestive glaucoma is typically associated with painful loss of vision and is more often unilateral. The condition involves a sudden increase in intraocular pressure, causing symptoms such as severe eye pain, nausea, and vomiting. Keratoconus (Option C): Keratoconus can lead to progressive vision loss due to the distortion of the cornea, but it usually presents gradually, not suddenly, and typically affects one eye more than the other initially. Iridocyclitis (Option D): Iridocyclitis (anterior uveitis) is usually associated with pain , photophobia, and redness in the affected eye. It does not cause sudden, painless loss of vision in both eyes.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a suitable application for a stenopic slit?

options.D: To find out the axis in astigmatism

questions.explanation: Corneal tattooing is a procedure in which pigment is injected into the cornea to alter its appearance. It is usually performed for cosmetic purposes like pterygium and pinguecula. Incorrect Option: Option A - Fincham's test: A stenopeic slit can be used in Fincham's test to differentiate the halos of acute congestive glaucoma and immature cataract. Option C - Optical iridectomy: A stenopaeic slit is used to determine the site of optical iridectomy. Option D - To find out the axis in astigmatism: A stenopaeic slit can be used to detect the axis of astigmatism. Reference: .

questions.question: At a distance of 60 m, what is the measurement of the angle formed by the largest letter on Snellen's chart?
questions.explanation: Incorrect Options : Options B, C, and D are incorrect. All the letters on Snellen’s chart subtend an angle of 5 minutes.

questions.question: A newborn is hypermetropic by
questions.explanation: near objects. In newborns, a certain degree of hypermetropia is considered normal. A refractive error of +2.5 D to 3.0 D is within the expected range for a hypermetropic newborn. Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.question: What should be the power of prescription glasses for a 50-year-old man who is presbyopic?
questions.explanation: additional positive or converging power to be added to the eye's optical system for clear near vision. It happens around the age of 40 years for an emmetropic person, less than 40 years in hypermetropic patients, and more than 40 years for myopic patients. At 40 years, around +1 D spherical lens is used to correct it. With every year that passes, around 0.5 D increases happen. So, +2D is the most appropriate power of prescription glasses for a 50-year-old man with presbyopia. Incorrect Options: Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an

questions.question: Identify the instrument.
questions.explanation: diagnostic tool used in ophthalmology to assess eye alignment and evaluate for ocular deviations or muscle imbalances. The Maddox rod consists of a cylindrical lens with parallel lines running along its length. The Maddox rod is typically used in the evaluation of horizontal strabismus (ocular misalignment) and is particularly useful in detecting and measuring the presence of a phoria (latent misalignment) or atropia (manifest misalignment). Incorrect Options: Option A - Maddox wing: The Maddox wing consists of two slits , the right sees the vertical white and horizontal red arrows and the left eye sees a vertical and horizontal line of numbers used for detecting the amount of phoria. Option B - Stenopic slit: It is useful to determine the site of iridectomy and helps in detecting the axis of astigmatism. Option D - Phoropter : A phoropter is a refractive instrument used during an eye examination to determine a patient's refractive error and prescribe corrective lenses. It contains a variety of lenses that can be adjusted to assess and refine a person's vision.

questions.question: What would be the recommended treatment for simple myopic astigmatism among the options provided?
questions.explanation: there is myopia (nearsightedness) along with astigmatism in one eye and normal other eye. This prescription that indicates a correction for myopic astigmatism is -1.00 DC × 180 Degree.. The -1.00 DC (D- dioptre and C - cylindrical) represents the cylindrical power, which addresses astigmatism. A negative cylindrical power indicates that the astigmatism is in the myopic (nearsighted) direction. The "× 180 Degree" denotes the axis of astigmatism. In this case, the astigmatism is at 180 degrees, meaning that the irregular curvature of the cornea or lens causing the astigmatism is aligned vertically. By prescribing -1.00 DC × 180 Degree, the correction aims to address both the nearsightedness (myopia) and the astigmatism in the correct axis. This combination is appropriate for a patient with simple myopic astigmatism. Incorrect options Option A: +1.00 DS This option indicates a simple hyperopic (farsighted) correction, which is not suitable for myopic astigmatism. Option C: -1.00 DS This option represents a simple myopic correction without addressing astigmatism. It only corrects for nearsightedness and does not address the irregular curvature of the cornea or lens that causes astigmatism. Option D: -1.00 DS – 1.00 DC × 180 Degree This option includes both a myopic correction (-1.00 DS) and an astigmatic correction (-1.00 DC × 180 Degree).

questions.question: Which of the following is not used to assess color vision?
questions.explanation: widely used bacterial test to assess the mutagenic potential of various substances. The test measures the ability of a chemical to induce mutations in certain strains of bacteria, indicating its potential to cause genetic damage. Incorrect Options: Option A - Holmgren wool test: The Holmgren wool test is a color vision test that assesses an individual's ability to match and identify colors using different shades of wool. It is commonly used to evaluate color vision deficiencies, particularly red-green color deficiencies. Option B - Ishihara chart: The Ishihara chart is a well-known color vision test that uses plates with colored dots or numbers embedded within backgrounds of different colors and shades. It is widely used to detect red-green color deficiencies and evaluate color vision abnormalities. Option C - FM 100 Hue test: The FM 100 Hue test is a color vision test that assesses an individual's ability to order and arrange colored caps or discs in a specific hue sequence. It measures the degree of hue discrimination and can help diagnose color vision deficiencies.

questions.question: Maximum visual field is seen in?
questions.explanation: 100 degrees. Incorrect Options: Option B - Nasal: The extent of the nasal region visual field is 60 degrees. Option C - Inferior: The extent of inferior visual fields is 70 degrees. Option D - Superior: The extent of superior visual field is the least, i.e., 50 degrees.

questions.question: In myopia, image is formed at:
questions.explanation: cornea is too steep, causing the focal point to fall in front of the retina rather than on it. This results in a blurred image for distant objects. Incorrect Options: Option B - Posterior to retina: This option is not correct for myopia. Myopia involves the focal point being anterior to the retina. Option C - On retina: Myopia results in the focal point being anterior to the retina, not on it. This can be corrected with concave lenses. Option D - Uvea: The uvea is not directly related to the location of the focal point in myopia.

questions.question: What are the advantages of using contact lenses instead of eyeglasses?
questions.explanation: reducing the prismatic effect that can occur with spectacles. Prismatic effect refers to the displacement of light as it passes through a lens, causing objects to appear shifted or distorted. Thicker the lens greater the prismatic effect. Contact lenses, being in direct contact with the eye, minimize the prismatic effect. Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are incorrect. These are not the advantages of using contact lens over spectacles.

questions.question: In myopia, an image is formed at?
questions.explanation: error of the eye where the eyeball is longer than normal or the cornea has excessive curvature. This causes light rays to focus in front of the retina instead of directly on it. Incorrect Options: Option B - Posterior to retina: In hypermetropia, image is found behind the retina. Option C - On retina: In emmetropic individual image is formed at the retina. Option D - None: In myopic patients the image is formed in front of the retina.

questions.question: The test given below in the image is used for :
questions.explanation: assessing stereopsis, which is the ability to perceive depth and three-dimensional vision The Titmus test is a three-dimensional polarized vectograph that comprises two plates presented in a booklet. To take the test, one needs to wear polarized spectacles before viewing the plates. The right plate shows a large fly, which tests for gross stereopsis, while the left plate shows nine squares, each containing four circles and animals. The test should be taken at a distance of 40 cm. Incorrect Options: Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an
